3.1 Rate of a
Chemical

that diamond is forever. Kinetic studies not only help us to determine
the speed or rate of a chemical reaction but also describe the
conditions by which the reaction rates can be altered. The factors
such as concentration, temperature, pressure and catalyst affect the
rate of a reaction. At the macroscopic level, we are interested in
amounts reacted or formed and the rates of their consumption or
formation. At the molecular level, the reaction mechanisms involving
orientation and energy of molecules undergoing collisions,
are discussed.
In this Unit, we shall be dealing with average and instantaneous
rate of reaction and the factors affecting these. Some elementary
ideas about the collision theory of reaction rates are also given.
However, in order to understand all these, let us first learn about the
reaction rate.
Some reactions such as ionic reactions occur very fast, for example,
precipitation of silver chloride occurs instantaneously by mixing of
aqueous solutions of silver nitrate and sodium chloride. On the other
hand, some reactions are very slow, for example, rusting of iron in
the presence of air and moisture. Also there are reactions like inversion
of cane sugar and hydrolysis of starch, which proceed with a moderate
speed. Can you think of more examples from each category?
You must be knowing that speed of an automobile is expressed in
terms of change in the position or distance covered by it in a certain
period of time. Similarly, the speed of a reaction or the rate of a
reaction can be defined as the change in concentration of a reactant
or product in unit time. To be more specific, it can be expressed in
terms of:
(i) the rate of decrease in concentration of any one of the
decrease in
reactants, or
(ii) the rate of increase in concentration of any one of the products.
Consider a hypothetical reaction, assuming that the volume of the
system remains constant.
$\rm R \to P$
One mole of the reactant R produces one mole of the product P. If
$\rm [R]_1$ and $\rm [P]_1$ are the concentrations of R and P respectively at time t₁
and $\rm [R]_2$ and $\rm [P]_2$ are their concentrations at time t₂ then,
$\Delta t \ \ = t_2 - t_1$
$\rm \Delta [R] \ \ = [R]_2 - [R]_1$
$\rm \Delta [P] \ \ = [P]_2 - [P]_1$
The square brackets in the above expressions are used to express
molar concentration.
Rate of disappearance of R
$\rm =\frac{Decrease \ in \ concentration \ of \ R}{Time \ taken} = - \frac{[R]}{t}$  (3.1)

Equations (3.1) and (3.2) given above represent the average rate of

Average rate depends upon the change in concentration of reactants
or products and the time taken for that change to occur (Fig. 3.1).

Units of rate of a reaction
From equations (3.1) and (3.2), it is clear that units of rate are
concentration time¯¹. For example, if concentration is in mol L-¹ and
time is in seconds then the units will be mol L¹s¯¹. However, in gaseous
reactions, when the concentration of gases is expressed in terms of their
partial pressures, then the units of the rate equation will be atm s¯¹.

From the concentrations of C₄H₁Cl (butyl chloride) at different times given Example 3.1
below, calculate the average rate of the reaction:
C4HCl + H2O → C4H₄OH + HCl
during different intervals of time.

that diamond is forever. Kinetic studies not only help us to determine the speed or rate of a chemical reaction but also describe the conditions by which the reaction rates can be altered. The factors such as concentration, temperature, pressure and catalyst affect the rate of a reaction. At the macroscopic level, we are interested in amounts reacted or formed and the rates of their consumption or formation. At the molecular level, the reaction mechanisms involving orientation and energy of molecules undergoing collisions, are discussed.

In this Unit, we shall be dealing with average and instantaneous rate of reaction and the factors affecting these. Some elementary ideas about the collision theory of reaction rates are also given. However, in order to understand all these, let us first learn about the reaction rate.

3.1 Rate of a Chemical Reaction

Some reactions such as ionic reactions occur very fast, for example, precipitation of silver chloride occurs instantaneously by mixing of aqueous solutions of silver nitrate and sodium chloride. On the other hand, some reactions are very slow, for example, rusting of iron in the presence of air and moisture. Also there are reactions like inversion of cane sugar and hydrolysis of starch, which proceed with a moderate speed. Can you think of more examples from each category?

You must be knowing that speed of an automobile is expressed in terms of change in the position or distance covered by it in a certain period of time. Similarly, the speed of a reaction or the rate of a reaction can be defined as the change in concentration of a reactant or product in unit time. To be more specific, it can be expressed in terms of:

(i) the rate of decrease in concentration of any one of the reactants, or
(ii) the rate of increase in concentration of any one of the products.

Consider a hypothetical reaction, assuming that the volume of the system remains constant.

R → P

One mole of the reactant R produces one mole of the product P. If [R]₁ and [P]₁ are the concentrations of R and P respectively at time t₁ and [R]₂ and [P]₂ are their concentrations at time t₂ then,

\[
\Delta t = t_2 - t_1 \\
\Delta[R] = [R]_2 - [R]_1 \\
\Delta[P] = [P]_2 - [P]_1
\]

The square brackets in the above expressions are used to express molar concentration.

Rate of disappearance of R

\[
= \frac{\text{Decrease in concentration of R}}{\text{Time taken}} = - \frac{[R]}{t}
\]

(3.1)

Rate of appearance of P \[ = \frac{\text{Increase in concentration of P}}{\text{Time taken}} = + \frac{[P]}{t} \] (3.2) Since, \( \Delta[R] \) is a negative quantity (as concentration of reactants is decreasing), it is multiplied with \(-1\) to make the rate of the reaction a positive quantity. Equations (3.1) and (3.2) given above represent the **average rate of a reaction**, \( r_{av} \). Average rate depends upon the change in concentration of reactants or products and the time taken for that change to occur (Fig. 3.1). ![Graphs showing instantaneous and average rate of a reaction](https://i.imgur.com/3Q5z5QG.png) Fig. 3.1: Instantaneous and average rate of a reaction **Units of rate of a reaction** From equations (3.1) and (3.2), it is clear that units of rate are concentration time\(^{-1}\). For example, if concentration is in mol L\(^{-1}\) and time is in seconds then the units will be mol L\(^{-1}\) s\(^{-1}\). However, in gaseous reactions, when the concentration of gases is expressed in terms of their partial pressures, then the units of the rate equation will be atm s\(^{-1}\). From the concentrations of C\(_4\)H\(_9\)Cl (butyl chloride) at different times given below, calculate the average rate of the reaction: \[ \mathrm{C_4H_9Cl + H_2O \rightarrow C_4H_9OH + HCl} \] during different intervals of time.
t/s 0 50 100 150 200 300 400 700 800
[C\(_4\)H\(_9\)Cl]/mol L\(^{-1}\) 0.100 0.0905 0.0820 0.0741 0.0671 0.0549 0.0439 0.0210 0.017
We can determine the difference in concentration over different intervals of time and thus determine the average rate by dividing \( \Delta[R] \) by \( \Delta t \) (Table 3.1). Example 3.1 Solution

Units of rate of a reaction
From equations (3.1) and (3.2), it is clear that units of rate are concentration time⁻¹. For example, if it is concerned in mol L⁻¹ s⁻¹ reactions, when the concentration of gases is expressed in terms of their partial pressures, then the units of the rate equation will be atm s⁻¹.

that diamond is forever. Kinetic studies not only help us to determine the speed or rate of a chemical reaction but also describe the conditions by which the reaction rates can be altered. The factors such as concentration, temperature, pressure and catalyst affect the rate of a reaction. At the macroscopic level, we are interested in amounts reacted or formed and the rates of their consumption or formation. At the molecular level, the reaction mechanisms involving orientation and energy of molecules undergoing collisions, are discussed.

In this Unit, we shall be dealing with average and instantaneous rate of reaction and the factors affecting these. Some elementary ideas about the collision theory of reaction rates are also given. However, in order to understand all these, let us first learn about the reaction rate.

### 3.1 Rate of a Chemical Reaction

Some reactions such as ionic reactions occur very fast, for example, precipitation of silver chloride occurs instantaneously by mixing of aqueous solutions of silver nitrate and sodium chloride. On the other hand, some reactions are very slow, for example, rusting of iron in the presence of air and moisture. Also there are reactions like inversion of cane sugar and hydrolysis of starch, which proceed with a moderate speed. Can you think of more examples from each category?

You must be knowing that speed of an automobile is expressed in terms of change in the position or distance covered by it in a certain period of time. Similarly, the speed of a reaction or the rate of a reaction can be defined as the change in concentration of a reactant or product in unit time. To be more specific, it can be expressed in terms of:

(i) the rate of decrease in concentration of any one of the reactants, or
(ii) the rate of increase in concentration of any one of the products.

Consider a hypothetical reaction, assuming that the volume of the system remains constant.

$$R \rightarrow P$$

One mole of the reactant R produces one mole of the product P. If [R]₁ and [P]₁ are the concentrations of R and P respectively at time t₁ and [R]₂ and [P]₂ are their concentrations at time t₂ then,

$$\Delta t = t_2 - t_1$$

$$\Delta [R] = [R]_2 - [R]_1$$

$$\Delta [P] = [P]_2 - [P]_1$$

The square brackets in the above expressions are used to express molar concentration.

Rate of disappearance of R

$$\text{Rate of disappearance of R} = \frac{\text{Decrease in concentration of R}}{\text{Time taken}} = -\frac{[R]}{t}$$

$$(3.1)$$

[Chemistry 62]

[Reprint 2025-26]

```markdown
Rate of appearance of P

$$
\frac{\text{Increase in concentration of P}}{\text{Time taken}} = \frac{[P]}{t} \tag{3.2}
$$

Since, $\Delta[R]$ is a negative quantity (as concentration of reactants is decreasing), it is multiplied with $-1$ to make the rate of the reaction a positive quantity.

Equations (3.1) and (3.2) given above represent the **average rate of a reaction, $r_{av}$**.

Average rate depends upon the change in concentration of reactants or products and the time taken for that change to occur (Fig. 3.1).

[Graph showing concentration of reactants and products over time with annotations for average and instantaneous rates]

**Fig. 3.1: Instantaneous and average rate of a reaction**

**Units of rate of a reaction**

From equations (3.1) and (3.2), it is clear that units of rate are concentration time$^{-1}$. For example, if concentration is in mol L$^{-1}$ and time is in seconds then the units will be mol L$^{-1}$s$^{-1}$. However, in gaseous reactions, when the concentration of gases is expressed in terms of their partial pressures, then the units of the rate equation will be atm s$^{-1}$.

From the concentrations of C$_4$H$_9$Cl (butyl chloride) at different times given below, calculate the average rate of the reaction:

$$
C_4H_9Cl + H_2O \rightarrow C_4H_9OH + HCl
$$

during different intervals of time.

| t/s  | 0  | 50  | 100  | 150  | 200  | 300  | 400  | 700  | 800  |
|------|----|-----|------|------|------|------|------|------|------|
| [C$_4$H$_9$Cl]/mol L$^{-1}$ | 0.100 | 0.0905 | 0.0820 | 0.0741 | 0.0671 | 0.0549 | 0.0439 | 0.0210 | 0.017  |

We can determine the difference in concentration over different intervals of time and thus determine the average rate by dividing $\Delta[R]$ by $\Delta t$ (Table 3.1).

[Example 3.1]

[Solution]

Reprint 2025-26

62 Chemical Kinetics
```

1.1 Rate of a Chemical Reaction

that diamond is forever. Kinetic studies not only help us to determine the speed or rate of a chemical reaction but also describe the conditions by which the reaction rates can be altered. The factors such as concentration, temperature, pressure and catalyst affect the rate of a reaction. At the macroscopic level, we are interested in amounts reacted or formed and the rates of their consumption or formation. At the molecular level, the reaction mechanisms involving orientation and energy of molecules undergoing collisions, are discussed.

In this Unit, we shall be dealing with average and instantaneous rate of reaction and the factors affecting these. Some elementary ideas about the collision theory of reaction rates are also given. However, in order to understand all these, let us first learn about the reaction rate.

Some reactions such as ionic reactions occur very fast, for example, precipitation of silver chloride occurs instantaneously by mixing of aqueous solutions of silver nitrate and sodium chloride. On the other hand, some reactions are very slow, for example, rusting of iron in the presence of air and moisture. Also there are reactions like inversion of cane sugar and hydrolysis of starch, which proceed with a moderate speed. Can you think of more examples from each category?

You must be knowing that speed of an automobile is expressed in terms of change in the position or distance covered by it in a certain period of time. Similarly, the speed of a reaction or the rate of a reaction can be defined as the change in concentration of a reactant or product in unit time. To be more specific, it can be expressed in terms of:

(i) the rate of decrease in concentration of any one of the reactants, or

(ii) the rate of increase in concentration of any one of the products.

Consider a hypothetical reaction, assuming that the volume of the system remains constant.

\[
\text{R} \rightarrow \text{P}
\]

One mole of the reactant R produces one mole of the product P. If $[\text{R}]_1$ and $[\text{P}]_1$ are the concentrations of R and P respectively at time $t_1$ and $[\text{R}]_2$ and $[\text{P}]_2$ are their concentrations at time $t_2$ then,

\[
\begin{align*}
\Delta t &= t_2 - t_1 \\
\Delta [\text{R}] &= [\text{R}]_2 - [\text{R}]_1 \\
\Delta [\text{P}] &= [\text{P}]_2 - [\text{P}]_1
\end{align*}
\]

The square brackets in the above expressions are used to express the molar concentration.

Rate of disappearance of R

\[
= \frac{\text{Decrease in concentration of R}}{\text{Time taken}} = - \frac{[\text{R}]}{t}
\]

(3.1)

From the concentrations of \( C_4H_9Cl \) (butyl chloride) at different times given above, calculate the average rate of the reaction:  
\[
\mathrm{C_4H_9Cl} + \mathrm{H_2O} → \mathrm{C_4H_9OH} + \mathrm{HCl}
\]

during different intervals of time.  
\[\begin{array}{ccccccccc}
 t/s & 0 & 50 & 100 & 150 & 200 & 300 & 400 & 700 & 800 \\
 \mathrm{[ C_4H_9Cl/mol L^{-1}]} & 0.100 & 0.0905 & 0.0820 & 0.0741 & 0.0671 & 0.0549 & 0.0439 & 0.0210 & 0.017
\end{array}\]

We can determine the difference in concentration over different intervals of time and thus determine the average rate by dividing \( \Delta[\mathrm{R}] \) by \( \Delta t \) (Table 3.1).
